A very well-written game. I hope anyone that enjoys stories where you get to make some tough decisions gives this game a try. The game has the same vibe as a TellTale game, but with the difference being there is a clear GOOD and BAD ending to this game. 

Checklist:

Music: Really good. BGM is easy to listen to, and the welsh/celtic rock song for the credits and main menu is very fun to listen to. 

Character design: Pretty good for pixels. I could tell the difference between almost every npc, and the character splash art at the end of the end felt very modern. 

Aesthetic: I really enjoy the style. It's very clean pixel art. It's not common to see games in this style so it was a refreshing take on art and game design. 

Accessibility: You need to be someone who enjoys reading a lot of text, as a large majority of the game is comprised of reading character dialogue. There is no voice overs, just some mumbled gibberish. 

Game difficulty: Pretty easy. The first few weeks seem like there are some tough choices, but you learn pretty quick to listen to the petitioner speaking to your King character about their plight and needs. Depending on how they sound when they ask for help, you can tell right away if you should actually give them aid, or call them out on their bull crap. 

Multiple playthroughs: Kinda. This game is only best played by doing two routes. Good route, or bad route. There isn't multiple endings aside from doing things the ethically right way, or the morally corrupt way. 

Price Point: I was gifted the game, so I don't know how expensive it is in the store. But if it's anything under $25 USD, then it's a pretty fair price point. I would still recommend buying it at a sale price though, for the sole fact that the game is REALLY short. You'll do an entire play through in about 6 hours. Maybe less if you're not too worried about your choices and the impact of your choices. 

Cons:
There's only one thing that really bugged me during the entire game. There is a pretty clear situation that pops up pretty early on that you (the player) probably would never agree to do. However, the situation is written into the story and isn't actually a choice the player can make. Long story short, I didn't enjoy being locked out of a choice that I would never have made myself, but unfortunately, it's just part of the story. One of those times where what the player expects from a Kingdom Management Sim RPG and what the narrator (or game dev) intended don't really align. I don't see the game devs as bad people for this forced choice, but at the end of the day, I still I wish I could've completely avoided the literal main plot of the game. 

Overall: The game is great. Definitely consider picking it up if you like a gripping story. It's a bit TOO short, so it might be a good idea to pick it up when it goes on sale. | Um excelente jogo de pixel art onde você irá perceber que nem sempre ser um rei é fácil, ter que lidar problemas do reino, todo o jogo político para conseguir vantagens com seus aliados que buscam também favores para sim, e também o apelo emocional que ele faz você se conectar com os personagens e sentir as perdas, mesmo sendo um jogo leve e com gráficos não avançados, em questão de narrativa, ele é sensacional, valeu cada centavo, um ótimo jogo | não compre, todos os arrependimentos que você tem por ter feito más escolhas na sua vida miserável não se compara ao que você vai sentir com esse jogo | O gerenciamento de recursos é relativamente fácil e simples, mas a história e a atmosfera do jogo é muito boa, as escolhas não interferem muito na progressão em si, mas você tem que decidir com base na sua régua moral e isso pra mim é o ponto mais divertido do jogo, vale muito a pena! | Voici l'avis de ma fille qui a fini le jeu :

Yes, Your Grace est un jeu qui m’a profondément marqué. Merveilleux et tragique à la fois, il offre une expérience unique où l’on incarne un roi confronté à des décisions déchirantes pour le bien de son royaume et de sa famille. Chaque session de jeu me laissait submergée par un mélange d’émotions intenses, allant de la fierté à la tristesse, et parfois même à une profonde mélancolie.

Le jeu repose sur des choix multiples, encadrés par une trame principale déjà prédéfinie. Si les grandes lignes restent les mêmes, ce sont les détails qui changent en fonction des décisions, et c’est précisément là que réside toute la richesse du gameplay. Ces petits ajustements créent un sentiment d’impact réel, même si l’on sait que l’on avance vers une fin inévitablement teintée de sacrifices.

Sur le plan technique, Yes, Your Grace séduit par son esthétique rétro. Les visuels pixelisés, loin des standards 4K ultra-précis, apportent une chaleur et une authenticité qui collent parfaitement à l’ambiance du jeu. Le style graphique renforce cette immersion dans un univers médiéval où chaque décision semble peser lourd.

En termes de difficulté, obtenir la “bonne fin” n’est pas insurmontable, mais le vrai défi vient après, pour ceux qui veulent atteindre tous les succès. Certains d’entre eux demandent des choix moralement difficiles, comme laisser mourir des personnages importants. Et honnêtement, je n’y arrive pas. Mon attachement aux personnages m’en empêche : je ne suis pas comme Ivo, qui semble tuer sans sourciller, haha. 😉

En conclusion, Yes, Your Grace est un jeu qui sait captiver, non pas par son action, mais par les émotions qu’il fait naître. Il vous plonge dans un univers où le devoir et le sacrifice se mêlent, où chaque choix porte une charge émotionnelle intense. Ce n’est pas un jeu qui laisse indifférent, et c’est précisément pour cela que je le recommande vivement. Préparez-vous à vivre une aventure à la fois magnifique et déchirante.

Absolutely beautiful art style that does not give away the punishing gameplay. In As Far As The Eye, you play as the wind, guiding a nomadic tribe to safe land. I very much enjoy the different take on the resource-management genre, with the journey broken up into multiple halts and obstacles. The short-term goal is simply to make it to the next halt before the step counter runs out and the flood arrives. The non-combative gameplay focuses on harvesting different resources instead, and actually provides a decent goal-oriented focus within which to use them.

Since each halt is procedurally generated, with varying amounts of ressources available, planning the journey ahead is essential for a realistic chance of making it to The Eye. Resources must be carefully managed, since they are simultaneously needed for the journey and the progression of the tribe per halt. At the beginning, I often struggled with rations and faced starvation among my Pupils. Only after many hours spent figuring out the mechanics, the gameplay finally started to feel fair. The challenge lies clearly in the fact that mistakes can’t be undone, with the single save file being overridden every turn.

Overall, I enjoy the simplicity of the gameplay, setting up camp over and over again, strategically placing buildings, and managing resources. The task-based progression of the tribe fosters a sense of attachment to the success of the Pupils. And I particularly love seeing them shapeshift into animal spirits based on their assigned trades. Although limited, the lore of As Far As The Eye fits seamlessly with the gameplay mechanics. This even makes me appreciate that excess resources gathered and left behind count against the final score, since the Pupils live in harmony with nature. | 6.5/10 - Decent

Buy on sale.  Worth the campaign and a run or two.  I can't remember how much I paid for it but about $10 CAD feels reasonable.

Really cute game.  Pretty decent challenge and strategy.  Satisfying to play once you learn.

Tip: 1. Start training a druid early.  2. If you can't find your pupils, look for their balloons.

If I had anything interesting to say, it would be that the bottlenecks between halts serve to really narrow my focus.  I'm not talking about the requirements to reach a halt, I'm talking about the inventory bottlenecks to reach it.  I found myself caring less and less about my pupils, their really cool skill trees, and what capabilities I could unlock, because I would likely need to throw away resources anyway to make room for food and the one mobile building I threw together.  It's really hard to get extraction up and running without a good supply of food for the beginning of each halt.  But the amount of food that requires takes up most of your caravan's inventory, making it hard to build anything right out of the gate.  
If I could change one small thing that would make the game significantly better, it would be to double the amount of food per stack in the caravan's inventory.  That would open up way more possibilities for interesting choices per run on what buildings to make mobile and what resources to take with you. | nicely done city builder in turn based | 氛围感拉满了

I still want to like this game. It's not that it could have been so much more, it's not that the 4x and combat elements are still too disconnected. It's quite simply that the actual gameplay is not fun. 
The case study that prompted me to write this review:
I'm playing a greedy game where I'm the only civ on my relatively large continent. I pick England and build Strongholds in various strategic locations. I own the whole continent and have lots of tech and buildings but a fairly small army - just enough to strongly defend a single attack point. I begin building ships to explore the world. I finally encounter another civ, then another. The world congress begins almost immediately. One of the civs demands 2000 gold from me. I naturally refuse. They push the issue to congress. I don't have an embassy yet, so I can't do anything about that, but fine. They won't be able to break into my continent. They pillage one of my two harbors. This gives them enough warscore to enforce peace, get the 2000 gold plus another 2400 gold for war reparations. I'm in bankruptcy. I work my way out of it. They demand 2000 gold again and now I can't refuse because my people don't want war.
What is the gameplay here? Pillaging a single district is enough to instantly end a war and enforce demands strong enough to cripple the enemy until you can immediately send more demands and declare war again? The war didn't even last long enough for me to attempt to fight it. I wouldn't mind if they enforced demands after they had landed a force and begun sieging my cities or thoroughly pillaged my entire coastline, but it was one single district. Honestly most games seem to end with one stupid mistake or lucky break, which is already not that fun, but you throw mechanics like that in and it just isn't worth trying anymore. | 好好好，今天是2025年2月7号，那边文明7发售，Epic就把人类免费送了是吧。 | I love this game. That Civ 7 is copying a lot of the mechanics that made this game different should tell you everything you need to know. | 慎玩。解决了文明系列的大部分问题，参考了文明系列的0项优点。 | 人类议会做的什么玩意？会议让你割让领土，拒绝就开战然后就给你30支持度，关键你看不见人家，你打不着人家。每回合降支持度，拖到回合结束强制失败，直接把首都割给ai。你这是什么设计?
The purest deck builder there is, an absolute masterpiece of a game. | This is a much better execution of this game than prior versions.  Nice job.

This is the best game I have ever played!

The story, the graphics, the art, the music... everything is incredible.

I have replayed the game (you're meant to play it more than once!) more than 20 times, and I am really close to achieving ALL possible endings. The first run WILL break your heart in the best way possible, and will make you want to play again and again until you reach your perfect ending.
No run is overly similar to the others in my opinion, as you can always find out one more detail about a character, or unlock one more dialogue you hadn't seen before.

The card game is very cool, but does not affect the storyline too much (unless you put in in hard mode), but if you don't like it there is the possibility to skip them completely.

There are different characters that you can befriend and/or romance (romance is not mandatory), each with their quirks, flaws and individual backstory. I think no character is too "perfect", too "good" or too "bad", as there is always some perspective from which they can seem the opposite. Through these characters, the game explores themes, such as love, loss, unhealthy obsession, mental health and abuse. However, although the themes are heavy, it is not felt throughout the game, and the playthrough remains pleasant, yet makes you reflect a lot.

Moreover, unlike many other games, almost EVERY SINGLE CHOICE you make will somehow affect the story you get. With a single conversation you can save or break someone, but not to worry, if you don't get what you want, you can always play again and make it better.

Last but not least, the music. The music is absolutely incredible, and the only song with lyrics from the game (you'll know when you hear it!) was among my Top 5 listens in 2024. The soundtrack is paired flawlessly to the scenes in the game, and makes the moments much more immersive.

This game means so much to me, it changed my life I could even say. So do yourself a favour and play it. | On the downside, I personally found this game a bit twee and heavy handed. That said, I liked it enough to play multiple times through. While I found the characters to be more like caricatures, the art is beautiful, the soundtrack is lovely, and the setting and gameplay are unique and interesting. It's definitely a good choice for a mild, comfort game. | It's so amazing. Out of most of the visual novel-esque, and choice heavy story games ive played. I'd say this one is probably the best, so much can change based on your choices and all the characters are so well written and interesting, even the ones that you'd think are just annoying. 
The game definitely goes places too, it never got boring and i was excited the whole time. Even the setting itself is super interesting and just fun to learn about. There is also a small addition of almost balatro like card challenges. Making straights and flushes and using the memories from choices you make as cards to succeed or fail at things. Its almost a roguelike with all the different cards you can get. I think this small bit of gameplay really helps round out the experience, it prevents it from being just one big book that you sit there and read for hours, it helps break up the reading with a little gameplay other than choices. The game is definitely better for it. | i love this game so much it is so replayable i see something new still every run and ive played like 6 lives | I don't know how to feel about this game. I wish Steam did starred reviews and not just Yes or No.

On the plus side, this is a beautiful game, with a really unique story, some of the most weirdly deep worldbuilding for a game in its genre (did not expect that at all!), and a gorgeous art style. The gameplay loop is fun and relaxing, and I really enjoyed playing it. It's fun watching your friends grow up around you, the story gets surprisingly serious at times, the choices you make do actually matter, and it has a lot of replay value. It's got some interesting takes on common scifi ideas, like a living planet, psionic aliens, nonlinear time, and the dangers of fascist ideology taking over a space colony. The worldbuilding is really cool, and the ecosystem is thought out in a kind of mindblowing amount of detail.

However.... some of the writing choices are awkward, clunky, and strange. I'm assuming the target audience are teenagers, so a lot of was easy to ignore as just "this was not written for me," but there are two things that sat really uncomfortably.

First, you can totally customize your character's sexuality and gender identity, including being a bioengineered genetic experiment, but you cannot be intersex, and that feels kind of bad when the rest of the game has ticked all of the representation boxes. The "I" in LGBTQIA does not exist in I Was a Teenage Exocolonist, but everything else does, so... It really sticks out, and feels like the creators were just trying to tick boxes to market the game better to teenagers. I tried to wave it away as part of the critique - the game subtly implies a few times that your parents are consciously rebelling against the planned breeding programs of the colony mindset - but then my colonist got older.

So, when you're about 16 (and maybe the option exists earlier than this, not sure), you start getting the option to flirt with grown adults. Notably, Utopia, the chief scavenger. It's a truly strange writing choice that only gets worse once you meet Sym. While I'm pretty sure you can only meet Sym once you're an adult, Sym is a very old alien who has been watching you since you were a little kid, protecting you the entire time you were growing up, has been intruding in your mind via psychic dreams, and from the moment you meet Sym the game tries to railroad you into a speed romance. I think it's for dramatics, because they die immediately, but it's still extremely uncomfortable given Sym is not the only adult with romance dialogue. Real, human writers made this game and chose to let your teen try to romance adults who watched them grow up from a little kid. It's not great. The only upside is that you are thankfully not forced to click on these options.

I don't hate the ending as much as most of the reviewers do. I think meeting your astral self after death is a nice poetic moment and a bit of fourth wall breaking to allude to the game's replayability. You're meant to replay this game a few times, and that's what the dialogue is about. I'm looking forward to trying to get different outcomes.

I just wish that I could give this game 3 or 4 stars instead of a single yes or no. If you like dating sims, this will probably be fun until the end, because none of the romances as far as I can tell actually work out in the end. I just wanted to play a fun scifi story game with pretty artwork and didn't care about that much, so this delivered that. If I had a teen, I'd probably recommend this game to them, because it seems like a fun way to explore your identity and learn about its ideas and themes. But it also makes me uncomfortable, and not in the "empowered to fight fascism" way that the game developers probably intended. I'm sure that some teen will really enjoy playing this game and seeing themselves in the characters, but I'm not sure it works for me.

... Also, it's just kind of cruel that the character who spends her entire childhood talking about how much she hates that she's being groomed by the adults around her to be a babymaker one day (Nem) ends up in an abusive marriage as an adult. I get that it's probably supposed to be commentary but it just feels meanspirited? If this is going to bother you, you probably shouldn't pick up this game, because I'm unclear on if you can prevent this ending.

I bought my copy tonight and played the tutorial and a full game against the AI. I think there are some opportunities for DAISU but overall the gameplay itself is solid.

Opportunities:
- Tiles could be clearer on zoom in. I like that the text is there, but I want to explore the art on those tiles too. I want a button to do a big zoom like I can do on Tabletop Simulator or Tabletopia.
- The tutorial has text that cannot be sped up and it doesn't always fit in the text bubble. That needs to be a) easily skippable and b) fit in the text bubble. I know you need to read the text, but you shouldn't be guessing how fast I can read. I can read much faster than the "next" text arrow appears.
- Play Local has New Game and Tutorial buttons that appear to be greyed out, but they aren't. And you're supposed to click them.
- When playing with AI, you can't see what your partner drew/chose for use in your castle, so you can't synergize with them. This led to me making decisions for my castle in a vacuum.
- I finished the second tutorial, but it never acknowledged I finished it. It just wouldn't accept feedback anymore and I had to hit escape and 'exit' to go back to the menu.
- Music sometimes behaves odd. Leaving the tutorial to the main menu made the music abruptly stop and then go to a new music track. Perhaps a fade out and fade in would be less jarring.
- The green "Ok" or select button is an odd design choice, it doesn't feel like it matches the same aesthetic of the rest of the game, but I find myself punching the spacebar to accept my changes anyway. It's not a real big deal.

All of that said, I really enjoyed my time with BTCoMKL. The beta was ROUGH on my PC, it was very choppy, very jerky, this has been completely resolved. It runs so quick and it says all settings are on Epic despite me not having a gaming laptop at all. It's a cheap Dell my father-in-law bought that I put a SSD in.
Everything I love about BTCoMKL is still here in the PC version except for the plotting and planning with my partner. BUT it did feel significantly better to crap on one of my castles to try and take the lead from the AI who had the lead.

I like how quick the gameplay was. It was a delight. I hope the online lobby picks up. I think the price for the game was fair too. Of course I always find myself wanting to wait for a Steam sale but I'm not much of a PC gamer, so I typically have no problem waiting. That said, I don't regret not waiting. Congratulations Team Daisu.

Oh, one more item of delight I wanted to mention.. I love how adding tiles to the castle actually causes the castle to grow behind you. You see walls come up and towers rise. It's a very neat effect that made me smile a couple of times. Also, great job identifying the castles by color. That made it very easy to identify which castle I was working with. | Actually, the only way I would play this game is through this app: unlike the board game, this digital version permanently displays your and your opponents' score throughout the entire game.  In the board game you had no idea how well you or your opponents are doing, except until the very end.  This digital version totally solves that.  I own the physical game, but I will provably almost never play it again, unless one of my friends desperately requests it. And finally, the interface of this (digital) game and the overall design is done near-perfectly.  Kudos to the programmers. | Очень хорошо перенесли в цифру настольную игру. Не понимаю негативных отзывов, это же цифровая настолка и ожидать от неё большего бессмысленно.

Интерфейс сделан удобно, переключение между замками на кнопки "1" и "2", убрать интерфейс для выбора бонуса на "Tab", ну и самое главное - автоматический подсчёт очков. Как же это напрягало в конце игры всё посчитать, а потом ещё раз пересчитать чтобы ничего не забыть (и хорошо если в обоих случаях всё сошлось). С другой стороны кто-то может сказать, что ушел некий азарт от того, что в картонной версии ты лишь приблизительно прикидываешь в уме какой из двух твоих замков впереди по очкам и пытаешься балансировать. Всё же я считаю, что видеть очки по каждому замку сразу добавляет расчётливости к выбору в каждый ход.
Игра так же автоматически предлагает выбор бонусов по трём и пяти одинаковым комнатам чтобы не забыть. Ну и самое главное, что в игре грамотно реализовали возможность игрокам в онлайне принимать совместные решения, а в случае, если игроки не достигают консенсуса, то игра автоматически принимает за игроков наиболее выгодное (по её мнению) решение, исходя из выбранных игроками тайлов и ситуации на столе.
Итого: играть комфортно, никакого фидлинга. | The game gets super unfun when the ai will intentionally screw up your shared castles but will always make the best plays on castles shared between themselves.

好玩，剧情和关卡很新奇，刚开始玩的时候不用小心翼翼，除非看攻略走正确路线，要不然都大差不差 | What I enjoyed:
At first I started this game trying to go in blind. I greatly enjoyed playing the various cards and discovering various interactions and hidden away tidbits in each area and loved being rewarded when I completed small side jobs in each chapter with a new card that gave me new strategies. Plenty of parts of the game have various conclusions & ways to complete tasks that make it fun. Bribe, boast, threaten, discourage or simply defeat enemies during combat, lots of fun routes to play. Sometimes there are even story related resolutions to a conflict via certain items. Some events end differently depending on the items you have on hand or number of pursuers, an early example is the prison break having a satisfyingly obvious difference between having pursuers VS no pursuers. You can even be rewarded depending on how well you perform certain story events. The game has certain consequences along the story as well if you rack up a body count. The game is designed to be played multiple times through each avenue to reach the finish line, and certain knowledge previously obtained helps make future runs easier (figuratively & literally, as prison break has multiple entrances and one can literally be recalled in game and is given as a card item).

What I hated:
There is no skip dialogue or cut-scene button, and for a game that is LITERALLY about replay-ability this is fairly unacceptable. And considering a release date of 2022 that issue isn't likely to be resolved. To top it all off, if you BEAT the game, your save becomes disabled for some insane reason and it simply says congratz thanks for playing (so bear that in mind for true ending pursuit, or lookup how to copy over your save and finish it on a secondary file). Some routes have only a single conclusion to reach, and if you lack the cards to get there or don't understand you might replay a chapter over and over again being stuck and walking in circles not understanding the objective. While you do unlock new cards, they are only for THAT RUN, meaning even tho the games story literally circles back until you reach the "true ending" you lose those new abilities. I personally found this disappointing as getting new tricks only to lose them feels bad.

What I recommend:
If you purchase this game, understand that unless you follow the guide on the forum you WILL fail a few missions or intentionally restart them. And you will have to sit through some dialogue you've already heard until you can get back to the fun. There is lots of fun finding where cards can be used, conventionally and unconventionally (elephant sneeze) and it honestly feels very well thought out in some area's and not so much in others. Near the end you WILL find some "not so obvious" clauses that, so far as i've seen, have only one proper resolution. There is only one walkthrough for this game that I have found and its not all encompassing but DOES get you to the finale, so even if you get frustrated with walking circles you will have a cheat sheet, don't hesitate to use it.

The game is fun, but unless the developer finally decides to fix the lack of dialogue & cut-scene skip for something you will see multiple times, its definitely not for everyone. I would very much recommend the game, but definitely understand "what" you are getting does have a few missing key features and poor design choices in general & later chapters (some are my opinion, some are factual "why is this feature missing"). | 好玩，风格类似跑团桌游，通过探索不同地点和它们产生交互。缺点是回档功能在结局出现后就不能使用，导致有时剧情突然结束，产生大量重复工作。 | I really like this game for his gimmicks. - Cheaters, a lot of them (rare lets you do all the work videoreporting them and still do barely anything)
- Desync, hitreg / actionreg, rubber-banding, disconnects, stutter, overall lag, miserable latency, underdeveloped MS Server. 
All of this is getting worse and worse with every update, despite the devs promises for years now.

From a devs perspective: They dug their own graves when they didn't see what a great debug opportunity Arena could have been and instead did everything backwards. 
A minimal game mode with no active events or pve code would be a great debugging platform for underlying problems. This would have also given the possibility of testing updates with more or less a 15-29 mins timeframe for: max lost time for players, time to next possible update without interrupting games and reverting back at any time in case of failure.

But what do I know, I'm just a programmer who likes to game.

 | The game itself is fantastic—the ship and wind mechanics, PvP battles, and especially the stunning wave animations make for an incredible experience. But in its current state, I cannot recommend it. The game is plagued with exploits and, worst of all—cheaters.

[h2]But hey, you can just report them, right? Sure! You just need to follow these SIMPLE steps:[/h2]

[list]
[*]Pre-record all your gameplay or use an instant replay feature (Don't have a high-end PC? Too bad!)
[*]Manually gather evidence and put together a solid report.
[*]Submit the report through a long, outdated browser-based process with strict criteria (such as capturing the cheater's nametag—which is much harder than it sounds).
[*]Deal with ridiculous limitations—only five evidence files per report, each under 50MB. If your files are too big, you’ll need to upload them elsewhere.
[/list]

Easy peasy, right? And even if you do all that and receive confirmation that the cheater was banned, it's just a minor inconvenience for them. Why? Because of ban evasion. Without going into too much detail, they can simply create a new account in under five minutes—without even repurchasing the game.

[h2]But I still like the game. Can I give feedback, suggest solutions, or discuss the cheater problem with the community?[/h2]

Whoa, whoa! Easy there, champ. Turns out, that’s not allowed either. Apparently, players are only supposed to report cheaters and trust that the devs are “working on it.” But hey, give them time—it’s not like this game has been out for over five years, right? 😃

Here’s part of a response from a staff member on the official Sea of Thieves forums:

"[...] Dropping anchor here as while we know this comes from a good place and of wanting to make the game better, and we do as well, the forums is not the space to discuss solutions when it comes to these things. This is because only the internal team know of what is and isn't possible and it is not something that is easily solved or has a quick solution. [...]"

[h2]To summarize:[/h2]

Reporting a single cheater takes far too much time. And if we consider the time a player loses at the hands of a cheater, let’s not forget:

[list]
[*]You could lose a boat full of treasure (representing two or more hours of gameplay).
[*]You could lose an Hourglass streak that took several hours to build.
[*]And now, on top of that, you’re expected to waste more of your time filing a detailed report—a job that shouldn’t be yours in the first place.
[/list]

[h2]To be fair...[/h2]

They do fix exploits—eventually.
But if you don’t mind a game infested with cheaters, go ahead—it’s a great game.
And always remember: they're working on it. 😉 | Ein harmonisches Spiel aus zusammenarbeit deiner Crew (komplett gelogen), und dir selber als Captain (ist immer unklar wer der Captain ist). [h1] КАРТОЧНЫЙ IDLE: ПУТЕШЕСТВУЕМ ПО МИРАМ [/h1]

[code] [b] Creature Card Idle [/b] - idle-игра с элементами построения колоды, разработанная Fordesoft и изданная ими же. Игра вышла в раннем доступе Steam в декабре 2019 года и на данный момент имеет чуть менее 90 отзывов, из которых лишь 68% положительных что в сумме дает игре "смешанный" рейтинг. У меня впечатления весьма средние, почему - рассказываю ниже. [/code]

[u] [b] ๑۩۩๑ КОНЦЕПЦИЯ ๑۩۩๑ [/b] [/u]

Так уж сложилось, что карточные игры - это мой основной жанр Srteam. За годы игры в самые разные проекты удалось уже повидать многое, и временами, естественно, стандартное начинает приедаться, и хочется отыскать что-то совсем новое. Один из вариантов - посмотреть, что-то на стыке жанров. И Creature Card Idle - как раз такой случай. 

Перед нами - типичная idle-игра. Иными словами - готовьтесь к долгому и кропотливому игровому процессу, игра в котором может растянуться на часы, дни, недели, месяцы... не будем о грустном. Давайте лучше о геймплее.  

[u] [b] ๑۩۩๑ ГЕЙМПЛЕЙ ๑۩۩๑ [/b] [/u]

Итак, как может выглядеть гибрид idle и карточной игры? Я, по началу, не очень хорошо себе это представлял. Ролик и скриншоты на странице CCI ясности мне не добавили, поэтому, дождавшись скидки, я решил-таки опробовать сие чудо. В чем смысл игры? 

На момент начала партии у нас имеется одна карта существа, а также поле с клетками, большая часть которых находятся в закрытом состоянии. Поместив карту на открытую клетку, мы тут же начинаем получать приток золота. Накопив достаточно монет, можно купить еще рабочих, или открыть больше плиточек для размещения карт. Чем сильнее ускорится тем получения золота. тем больше возможностей откроется перед вами - открыв все клетки для размещения карт, можно обратить внимание на бустеры - наборы с совершенно новыми картами, у каждой из которых есть свое особое свойство, позволяющее вам еще сильнее ускорить получение денег. Некоторые карты хороши сами по себе, иные эффективны только в комбинациях, но их совместный эффект порой может превзойти даже самые выгодные сочетания одиночных картонок. В общем, подумать будет над чем.

Однако, сколько карт ни выбивай и какие комбинации ни придумывай, рано или поздно вы все равно упретесь в одну из нескольких единственно-выгодных комбинаций, и менять что-то будет уже бессмысленно. Но на этом игра не заканчивается. Накопив достаточно средств, вы открываете новый мир, и попадаете в совершенно другую вселенную, действующую по схожим правилам, но более усложненным. В новом мире место золота займут древесина и металл, и, что интереснее - добывать два ресурса одновременно будет не так-то просто, потому что карты, дающие один ресурс, непременно будут поглощать другой. Здесь подбирать сочетания карт станет вдвойне сложнее. 

Но и это еще не предел. Пройдя все особенности и разобравшись в тонкостях колодостроения в новом мире, вы, накопив достаточно ресурсов, сможете открыть третий мир. И вот здесь-то и начинается самое большое веселье. Спойлерить не буду, но скажу, что с каждым разом будет определенно сложнее и разнообразнее.   

Графически игра представляет собой нечто весьма простенькое и неказистое, дизайн минималистичен и не всегда удобен в использовании, а картинки на картах так и вовсе взяты из открытых источников. Музыкальное сопровождение сносное, но быстро надоедающее. Имеется небольшой набор достижений Steam, половину из которых можно выбить буквально за час игры, что для idle-игр нетипично. Русского языка нет, но текста, если не считать свойств некоторых карт, также особо не представлено.   

[u] [b] ๑۩۩๑ ПЛЮСЫ И МИНУСЫ  ๑۩۩๑ [/b] [/u]

+ Оригинальная смесь idle-игры и построения колоды 
+ Несколько миров-уровней с разными условиями 
+ Интуитивно-понятные правила, низкий порог вхождения
+ Система перерождения с усилением возможностей 
+ Набор достижений Steam
+ Умеренный ценник и частые скидки

- Сыроватый дизайн, местами не очень удобные диз.решения
- Унылый набор звукового сопровождения
- Игра быстро заинтересовывает, но так же быстро и надоедает 
- Русского языка нет (уровень английского - базовый)

Стоит отметить, что большую часть хейта игра словила за счет красных отзывов игроков, которые жалуются на нестабильную работу CCI, частые вылеты, баги и глюки в ходе прохождения. За 2,5 часа лично у меня ничего подобного не случилось, но кто его знает - может, если поиграть подольше, и не такое вылезет.   

[u] [b] ๑۩۩๑ СТОИТ ЛИ ИГРАТЬ?  ๑۩۩๑ [/b] [/u]

Меня тут периодически приходят погрызть всякого рода хейтеры, мол, что можно понять об idle-игре, если играл в нее всего пару часов? И вот это как раз тот случай, когда понятно абсолютно все. За указанное время я успел посмотреть большую часть имеющегося контента, без чтения гайдов вычислить все топовые комбинации карт на каждом из этапов, и выбить более 50% достижений, после чего у меня закономерно возник вопрос - а что еще осталось делать-то в этой игре? Так и не найдя ответа, в итоге пишу отзыв - игра, в целом, довольно средненькая, имеется ряд интересных фишек, но надолго она вас едва ли задержит. Особенно, если не любите карточные механики.

Firstly, know that this is a farming sim game with wuxia vibes. If you had hoped for interesting martial arts, high stakes drama, conflicting ideologies, relations or conflicts between multiple sects, and wise masters to learn from then you won't find them here. This game is about farming, fishing, raising bees and silkworms, and building a small village (your sect). In doing that your character learns something about cultivation, but the MAIN thing is farming. Honestly, I don't even know what the Guiyun sect values other than they seem to be 'good guys'.

Secondly, know that the game has a tremendous amount of grind. Truly monumental amounts. Even with the Jade Pendant upgraded to level 11 (maybe the max upgrade to level 12 helps...?) it is a ton. By the second spring I had reached my cultivation limit, had a fully upgraded house, had completed every side quest, and had an almost unlimited amount of money. Then I realized that there was a sect journal, and I had neglected one person and so the main story line had been delayed. None of the things I did counted; once you reach the point where you need to breakthrough you simply stop learning. None of the experience you gained applies to the next level, meaning you have to grind it all out again. While this mimics a sort of real life plateau that people come to in periods of training or development, it isn't fun in a game. It took a long time to get to a point where I could breakthrough because countless quests require you to 'wait one day'. It completely breaks the immersion when you end up sleeping for 23 hours, getting a letter, and sleeping for 23 hours.

Don't get me wrong, I have had fun in the first 60 hours of gameplay. I like the farming and the fishing and the people and the dungeons. Yet at this point everything feels very artificial. The gaps between breakthroughs are HUGE, the tutors you can hire never seem to get better, and now I have to do another kind of farming in the Blessed Land... 

I hate the Blessed Land crops. They really feel like an extremely inorganic way of padding the length of the game. You constantly need to dig up crops in order to plant new ones of different types, you have to move these flags around, you have to wait until the next day for any seeds to contribute energy... why? It's all so arbitrary and tedious. I'm already an excellent farmer. I'm already an excellent combatant. I look cool and my house is fully upgraded and I have more money than I can spend. Yet I have to spend AGES growing these crops...

In order to grow them efficiently I need more materials, which means going into dungeons, and that is a bore. I have only made it to the Blazing Sands dungeon and, from the looks of it, I have 4 or 5 more to look forward to. Visually they all have a cool look even if most of them are palette swapped versions of each other. The enemies have been different in each locale; despite having lizards everywhere some will bite and others shoot bullets and some have lasers. so there is diversity in how they attack you. Yet you have one main attack, a sort of sword beam, and it is extremely boring. You also do have spells, but I've never felt the need to use any other than the starting spell. It attacks a huge area, pierces enemies, and usually one shots opponents even if they share the same element. There are other elements for spells, but I have never once needed an advantage that way. 

So lets say you need Mirror Sand for a pot to grow your Blessed Land fruit faster... well, you can do a run in the Blazing Desert and, with certain blessings and luck, you might come away with enough Mirror Sand to make one pot... about ten units. Now you have to do that 8 more times. Then you have to do it for everything else that costs Mirror Sand, like houses and other upgrades. It is EXTREMELY tedious. 

You can eventually gain movement speed buffs from food and alchemy (you unlock food first, and from what I can tell, food is ALWAYS better for some reason). Once you do, you realize just how SLOW this main character is. Again, this isn't a wuxia game. You cannot train lightness of body, jump higher, or run faster (your character actually never gets better at ANYTHING they do. I guess you can upgrade stats like divinity and stance but throughout the whole game I have never noticed them making a difference in anything. Fishing is still slow. You never attack faster. Your tools and spells and things get better but YOU don't). The only way to gain a movement boost is via consumables most of which run out incredibly quickly. This contributes to just how frustrating the grind can be, at least until you can use blessings to make huge quantities of cabbage soup, then you just need to ensure you have tons of those ingredients. 

Finally, know that there are no deadlines or tension of any kind. Everything can wait. There are no emergencies, time limits, or stakes at all (...in quests that matter. There are some job board quests that have time limits and quick completion rewards but the quests themselves can be ignored and are eventually very trivial). This is fine for many people, but for me it just renders the whole activity pointless and artificial feeling after a while. There is no skill involved. The only obstacle between you and your goals is time... and I am finally reaching a point where I feel like my time is better spent elsewhere.

I do love the characters... I sort of want to know what happened to the sect... but everything is revealed so extremely slowly that it might as well not matter at all. With every story quest I complete someone asks me to do another chore or recruit another person but nothing really develops. At first it felt like I was making progress fixing the sect, but now I'm growing weird magic crops for no reason because my crops aren't magic enough...? I have enjoyed the time I've spent with Immortal Life, and I am a huge fan of wuxia, but this just feels like a job at this point. I leave crops in the field unharvested. I don't check the beehives anymore. I truly don't need to do any of it and don't want to do any of it either. 

I still recommend the game: it is fun for quite a long time, at least 40 hours playing and a full year of the game. Once you start to master the system, or if you are a power gamer, or if you seek external motivation, or if you are motivated by a developing story then maybe this isn't for you. If you do play it, I cannot recommend enough using the sect journal to be continuously completing the main story so you don't end up wasting your time.

差评，不喜欢 |         -Very enjoyable game that mixes farming with the cultivation from Chinese wuxia. In a world full of mostly stardew valley clones this stands out with a game-play loop that very different so for anyone seeking a different experience than what we are used to this is a game for you. The game initially is much more focused on farming, however as you continue to cultivate you will be able to do this faster from running around swinging two blades to harvest your entire field in seconds to having large clouds that can water 50 or so plots very rapidly and eventually the whole farming aspect becomes automated other then planting and harvesting. 

        -This is where you enter the 2nd phase of the game where the focus is no longer on farming but cultivating and completing the sect journal to rebuild the Guiyun sect. Finally phase 3 is once again a focus on farming extra special plants with the use of mystic tools. All the characters are relatively interesting and overall storyline was enough to keep me invested which is definetly a step up compared to many games in this genre. 

        -The combat is simple and is essentially a twin stick shooter game where you running launching flying blades and use spell-like abilities to do things such as conjuring tornadoes, breathing fire or throwing boulders at enemies. 

        -Also you don't need to sleep because you are a cultivator, you can to restore health, mana and stamina but it is not necessary so no rushing back to your bed every 10 minutes. 

        -The cooking mini-game caught me off guard and is extremely enjoyable

        -Game play really well on controller as well HOWEVER, you can't rebind the keys and b is accept while a is cancel which broke my mind the first few times I played it, you get used to it but it's definitely annoying the first time around.

        -My one real gripe with the game is that the sect journal has no tutorial so many players miss it, I see it all the time in the discussion section of steam. To anyone picking this game up for the first time make sure you pay attention to the sect journal you can access it by pressing escape, quests and then switching the tab to sect journal, it will tell you how to unlock the new quests and when you will unlock additional features like different dungeons, new sect members etc. If you don't do this you can find yourself locked out of content for ages because some of them have esoteric unlock conditions like be in this one spot between  10 and 12pm or check in on someone 7 times over 7 different days etc. | Very addicting to play. Living my cultivation dreams yesssss. Hope at the end there will be an option for Dao Companionship. Hoping for more cn games like this.

a really awesome pack that even with its weaker games (D&tD and Blather Round) they still manage to at least give a decent time with other players. And the other 3 games (Quiplash 3, Champ'd Up, and Talking POints) are EXTREMELY fun. Of the party packs i own, this is def my fav | Really great pack. I recommend you get it on sale however. | Where do I start. Champd up is an amazing game, absolutely love and recommend it, I don't think I've met someone who didn't enjoy that game. Quiplash, also a solid addition to the pack, although just a remake, and although this is an unpopular opinion, I really do enjoy the devils and the details. I think its a creative game and while it could have been executed better, provides a one of a kind experience. Altogether, this is a great pack and I recommend it | I'll rate the games individually based on how fun they are to play in a party [P] setting (friends/family in person) and on like a discord [D] stream (computers, virtual)

Champ'd Up - [P 4/5, D 6/5 (this game rocks)]
Quiplash 3 - [P 5/5, D 4/5]
Devils and the Details - [P 2/5, D 2/5]
Talking Points - [P 5/5, D 3/5]
Blather Round - [P 3/5, D 3/5]

Overall this pack is really good, I'd say it's worth | Oh hey, my profile picture is one of the devils from The Devils and the Details. Either way...

Tl;dr of my mini-reviews of each game: This pack is still very solid, even though with some games there are small "ughs".

---------------

Quiplash 3: Aesthetically one of the more unique ones of the Jackbox series, featuring claymation-style elements. Quiplash is Quiplash, you fill in the blanks of sentences and make a ha-ha. The only caveat I have with this version is the music - in the soundtrack it's fine, but during gameplay, it's intimidating even... but it's easily brushed off.

The Devils and the Details: Hhhhhhhh - mixed feelings. It's a group game where some tasks are independent, some require teamwork. You fill a bar with the tasks you do and move to the next day. Here, it really depends on the group of people you are playing with - playing with people other than those that you have vocal contact with is borderline impossible, just because of the teamwork-required tasks. Even then, this is something I occasionally play with a group of people and get joy out of it. Occasionally = far less than the other games, but still played.

Champ'd Up: To this day, still probably the best drawing game in Jackbox Packs. You draw characters based on a prompt, and then get a rival whose appearance you see, but don't know the prompt. Then they fight each other. It's so simple in concept, but really fun. Also, bonus points to the music - Andy Poland went hard and I appreciate it, really digging the electronic music mixed with march band drums. Kinda reminds me of Death Grips' earlier works through that.

Talking Points: Vocal improvisation, the game - speaking is mandatory in this game, and so, should be played with those with vocal contact. You get a topic for a slideshow, but don't know the pictures that a different player chooses for you. This game usually gets extremely restless and out-of-bounds, which can be really fun at times. Freeplay-mode for this is an odd choice.

Blather 'Round: This game is one of my go-to games when introducing Jackbox to other players (others being Tee K.O. and Guesspionage). You get a thing that you have to explain about with using cryptic words, and give "praise/discipline" to player-given answers (in other words, you can agree, or don't agree with a word to lead others onward). Fun and engaging, best with a big player group. This game should've gotten the Freeplay-mode, but I guess such wasn't picked up for the potential difficulty of giving custom words the prompts that the game gives you?

Game Name: There Is No Game: Wrong Dimension
Reviews:
[h1]《There Is No Game: Wrong Dimension》——一场浪漫的数字冒险[/h1]  

[u]“这里没有游戏。”真的吗？[/u]  
你有没有玩过一款游戏，一上来就死命告诉你：[b]“这里没有游戏”[/b]？还一本正经地劝你关掉应用去干点别的？《There Is No Game: Wrong Dimension》（以下简称T.I.N.G）就是这样一个[b]“假装自己不是游戏”[/b]的游戏，而你，很快就会发现自己被骗得心甘情愿。  

这不仅是一款游戏，它更像是一封来自开发者的情书——[i]献给游戏、献给玩家、献给那个依旧相信游戏能带来魔法的自己。[/i]  

[hr][/hr]  

[h1]浪漫的游戏，不止于玩法[/h1]  
在讨论玩法之前，我想先聊聊这个游戏带给我的感受：它[b]浪漫得不可思议。[/b]  
这里的浪漫，不是指玫瑰花和情人节，而是一种对创作的纯粹热爱，一种愿意倾注心血去[b]打破常规[/b]的坚持。  

T.I.N.G 不只是游戏，它是开发者[b]Pascal Cammisotto[/b] 用代码写下的情感表达。它用一种极具个人风格的方式，打破了我们对游戏的固有认知，让玩家不只是“通关”，而是在[i]体验、在对话、在共同创造。[/i]  

[hr][/hr]  

[h1]配音、对白与“活着的游戏”[/h1]  
如果你喜欢幽默、喜欢游戏玩梗、喜欢自嘲的风格，那这款游戏一定会让你[b]笑出声。[/b]  
整个过程中，最核心的“角色”——[b]旁白[/b]，几乎就是开发者本人的化身。他既是游戏的“灵魂”，也是你的“对手”，不断与你斗嘴、打破第四面墙、讽刺游戏业界的各种套路。  

[quote=旁白] “游戏里怎么可能有Bug？” [/quote]  
[quote=旁白] “免费游戏？哈哈，你以为真的免费？” [/quote]  
[quote=旁白] “勇者救公主？请你来点新意好吗？” [/quote]  

他会时不时嘲讽玩家的操作，又会在你卡关时稍稍透露一些线索。整个过程，像是在和一个幽默又有点傲娇的朋友对话。[i]这种做法，让T.I.N.G 有了一种“活着”的感觉。[/i]  

[hr][/hr]  

[h1]游戏的玩法？是“拆解”规则的过程[/h1]  
T.I.N.G 的玩法很难用传统分类方式去描述，它[b]既不是纯解谜，也不是纯点击冒险，而是一个不断打破自己规则的体验。[/b]  

[list]  
[*] 当游戏告诉你“这里没有游戏”，你要试图找到游戏的“缝隙”，看看能不能让它露出破绽；  
[*] 当按钮坏掉，你得想办法“修理”它，但也许修理的方式是[b]故意把它弄坏[/b]；  
[*] 当屏幕被锁住，你要做的可能是调节音量、晃动窗口、甚至调整自己的鼠标灵敏度……  
[/list]  

这种玩法带来的满足感，是一种“和开发者对话”的感觉——[i]像是你们在进行一场超越时间和空间的互动。[/i]  
[quote=开发者] “想玩游戏？不可能的！” [/quote]  
[quote=玩家] “好，那我就偏要找到能玩的部分。” [/quote]  

[hr][/hr]  

[h1]从2D到VR，从像素到3D，每个维度都有惊喜[/h1]  
T.I.N.G 还特别有意思的一点是——它[b]并不仅限于一个美术风格，而是不断切换“游戏维度”。[/b]  

[olist]  
[*] 你会进入一个[b]像素风的复古冒险游戏世界[/b]，体验传统RPG的荒诞感；  
[*] 你会来到一个[b]90年代的点击式解谜游戏场景[/b]，寻找线索破解谜题；  
[*] 甚至，你还会进入一个[b]类似VR的立体界面[/b]，感受空间感的变化……  
[/olist]  

[b]到底什么才是游戏？[/b]  
是画面？是玩法？是交互？还是，我们和它建立的那份联系？  

[hr][/hr]  

[h1]这款游戏，为什么能触动游戏开发者？[/h1]  
作为一个曾经的游戏策划，我在这个游戏里感受到了一种特别的共鸣。  

[i]我仿佛能看到开发者在某个深夜，面对着屏幕闪烁的代码，一边喝着咖啡一边苦笑，想着“玩家们真的会理解我在做什么吗？”[/i]  
[i]我能想象他敲下“这里没有游戏”这行字时，嘴角带着一丝恶作剧般的微笑，却又怀揣着满满的期待。[/i]  

因为我们都知道，做游戏[b]不是为了让玩家“过关”[/b]——我们想做的，是创造一种体验，让玩家可以真正[i]感受[/i]到什么。  

T.I.N.G 就是这样一个游戏。它不只是娱乐，更是一场开发者与玩家之间的交流，是对[b]“游戏”这一媒介的一次思考和探索。[/b]  

[hr][/hr]  

[h1]结语：这不仅仅是一款游戏，它是一种情感表达[/h1]  
T.I.N.G 不是一款传统意义上的解谜游戏，它是一场体验，一场打破第四面墙、挑战玩家认知的旅程。  

[b]它浪漫，[/b]是因为它把游戏当成了一种表达，而不是一个单纯的产品。  
[b]它浪漫，[/b]是因为它不讨好市场，而是忠于创作者的初心。  
[b]它浪漫，[/b]是因为它让我们意识到，游戏不仅仅是程序和代码，它可以拥有灵魂，可以成为人与人之间的桥梁。  

如果你喜欢充满创意、幽默风趣、能够挑战思维定式的游戏——[b]别再犹豫，去体验这场浪漫的“非游戏”吧。[/b] | ✅ Uma história super interessante, engraçada e emotiva
✅ Dublagem incrível
✅ Design lindo
✅ Trilha sonora da GiGi é marcante demais
✅ Recomendo qualquer um a experimentar
✅ Jogabilidade simples porém intuitiva demais
✅ Puzzles sensacionais
❌ Não tem nada negativo 

Com certeza, é um jogo que tem um espaço para ser um dos meus favoritos em meu coração. A jogabilidade do jogo é 'simples', porém é intuitiva demais por ser muito interativa com o narrador. Recomendo demais! | I watched a bunch of Let's-Plays for this game from Markiplier and then 100-percented it in a couple of hours. Really wish I played it for myself BEFORE I consumed the Let's-Plays, but the game still rocks anyhow! :D |

☑ https://vojtastruhar.github.io/steam-review-template | Très bon jeu  , l'histoire était unique est je me suis attaché aux personnages? j'ai adoré chaque instant et le style de gameplay était amusant je me demandais toujours ce que je ferai ensuite. Si je pouvais jouer à ce jeu pour la première fois encore une fois je le ferais volontier.

I know most people compare it to stardew valley, and while i do not think it right to judge games only by comparing them, i'll still say that i like roots of pacha way better. The pre-historic setting itches that part of my brain that loves historical settings. As an agriculture major, i hugely appreciate the fact that there is undomesticated and domesticated versions of every crop, and i think it would be really cool if the domesticated plants gave larger crop, too; as larger harvests were one of the major goals in the domestication process, alongside disease resistance and all, of course. The ideas and recipes make it so that you really want to grow every crop, instead of just mass-producing the most valuable one. It is also lgbtq+ and polygamy friendly, which, while i dont specifically care for, am sure a lot of folk appreciate. It also feels more wholesome, in a way; not that i dont love stardew valley, dont get me wrong; but even if you chose the community center route, stardew is still a largely money-driven game. Instead of fixing up a community center that npc's sometimes go to and you mostly forget about after maybe the second year; in roots of pacha it feels like you really are helping the community. Overall; great concept, nice soundtrack, your kids actually grow up and become human beings, you can trap or raise animals for meat, there is a genetics system for animals, great game all around. And also you can have a pet wolf. Come on now. Dont you want a pet wolf. | A fantastic iteration of the farming sim genre. The formula is familiar but the setting, storyline, and slightly altered mechanics make it stand out and not feel like a copy paste of other games. No combat so much more laidback than other games. Only complaint would be that the animal taming system can be a bit grindy and tedious if you want rare variations of animals. I had pretty much finished the game by the time I got an animal with maxed out stats. Some of the end game content does make getting variations easier, but breeding for stats still takes a long time for what feels like little reward. 
Other than that, it's probably my favorite farming sim that I've played and holds very well against the genre standard of Stardew Valley. | I do love a farming simulator, but this adds so much to the cozy aesthetic. The creativity in this game is unmatched and i have never seen so many fantasy, and historical elements in a game like this. I really do hope it gets the love it deserves | Ótimo jogo! Gosto do paradigma comunitário no qual algumas das mecânicas de progresso/desenvolvimento operam, mas na prática o jogo acaba mantendo uma logica de produção individualizada e desenfreada que já vemos em outros títulos semelhantes. Se tivesse um sistema de escassez de recursos faria muito sentido dentro da proposta e das premissas do jogo. De qualquer forma é bem divertido, a história é legal, tem bastante coisa pra fazer e gastar tempo. Recomendo | This is one of the best games I have ever played. it is so creative, so full of heart, and truly delightful to play across all aspects. 10/10 amazing love it wonderful!!!!!

Genres: Adventure, Casual, Simulation, Free To Play
Reviews:
This is a great game to DOWNLOAD and play. With so many character options you can create any type of Sim, even a FIT GIRL! You can also REPACK your belongings and move a new lot anytime. This game is a TORRENT of nonstop fun that i would recommend INSTEAD of similar titles! | убрали один из главных плюсов третьего симса - открытый мир. в третий симс можно было наигрывать сотни часов даже в базовую версию без допов, в этой же игре будет не интересно даже со всеми дополнениями, оно и понятно, взяли и специально разбили игру на миллиард комплектов ценники которых превышают стоимость современных ААА игр. вы там в адеквате? лень описывать все минусы этой игры, проще сказать что симс 4 хуже третьего во всех аспектах, да даже во второй больше смысла играть, там тоже закрытый мир, где нужно прогружатся между участками, но играть интереснее.
По сути в симс 4 играть интересно только на этапе строительства, потом только качать моды которые наверно являются самым большим плюсом этой игры. И это не то что бы круто. Обмазывать по фуллу придется, что бы посидеть тут подольше. Короче любой аналог симса размажет этот кусок деньгавыжимателя от отстойных EA.
1 февраля в стим добавили первый и второй симс, теперь играть в четвертый смысла вообще 0! хахахахахахахахаха! | Jogo base não há nada para fazer, coisas básicas de um jogo são pagas. Mas os mods e conteúdos personalizados salvam. | ゲーム内容は良いのですがEAのサポート体制が非常に悪く、何年も前にリリースされたDLCの不具合が放置されたままになっていたり、不具合を見つけても報告するまでのステップが難解であったりします。
せめてバグ報告くらいはゲーム内メニューからもう少し簡単に送信できるようにならないものでしょうかね？ | The game may be "free", but it isn't FREE. To have any amount of fun in this game is to buy the overly expensive DLC. You could download CC, but that can only go so far without having the DLC. $1300 for all of it?!?!?! Not even the sims 3 DLC is that much. This game is a shitty money grab and I am just waiting for Paralives to release.

很棒的遊戲，各種地形、陷阱、怪物的效果互動發揮得很好。
可以感受到製作者的各種小巧思。

 | 希望可以出更多的角色，付费也可以，游戏是好玩的，但是上手有点难度，前几局打了四个多小时一把没赢过。我是玩陷阵之志才了解到这类棋盘玩法的，迷失幻途的重复游玩性比较高，只可惜这一类游戏的受众就是这么回事，就是小众，希望作者能够坚持下去吧，提供多一些角色，丰富一下道具和地图，搞个无尽模式什么的，我原本也是试玩尝鲜，但是实在是好玩就补票了，希望可以鼓励到作者，反正出角色DLC我会支持。 | Another card game where I need to build a deck out of crap cards, (and can't "deck build" unless I have cash on hand (80 gold just to drop a card? WTF?)) but the enemies can feel free to do whatever they want because they don't have to follow the same rules I do.
Hmmm, I'd like to try easy mode. Oh, I can't because then it's absolutely worthless for progression. Can I try another class? Not until I've ground 100 thankless missions with classes I hate playing.
Seriously, why does anyone like this garbage?
I wish half of these card games would make enemies use cards instead of getting to just do free attacks. But balance is for MMOs and FPS shooters. Deck builders are always garbage because of nostalgia or whatever. | Very solid, I love the FFT-inspired artstyle, I do wish you could have other party members as thats a big part of the fun of tactical roguelikes but its still cool | 一部不错且让人上瘾（难得玩到凌晨2-3点）的佳作，可惜章节太短，就像打了一个序章一样。

[h1]Красивый мир, который я никак не могу вспомнить.[/h1]
Один из самых интереснейших рогаликов, в которые я играл. Здесь прекрасно всё: сюжет, механики, визуальная составляющая и саундтрек, но обо всём по порядку.

[h3]Сюжет[/h3]
Сюжет — по моему мнению, первый козырь игры, который цепляет сходу.
Прежний мир уже не вернуть, но мы помним — помним его части и по пути вспоминаем остальные локации и существ, в том числе и тех, кого мы не очень хотели видеть на дороге. Это завораживает и заставляет играть дальше, узнать мотивацию антагонистов и прочувствовать ощущения главного героя, его скорбь и груз его ответственности. Герой сам не помнит кто он такой, из-за чего и вытекает возможность смены класса. Мы не знаем его увлечений, но чувствуем в его словах... Надежду? Воодушевление? Не знаю.
Я прочёл все описания предметов, карточек и врагов, и могу сказать то, что тут всё продумано. Советую почитать на досуге, ведь это углубляет в мир игры. А ещё там написано всё от лица главного героя, что добавляет интереса к чтению.
[b]10/10[/b]

[h3]Механики[/h3]
Вам никто ничего не объясняет, вы всё должны пробовать на свой страх и риск. Нигде не напишут что за 10 гор/холмов вы резко вспомните ещё и о существовании гоблинов, или же о том, что вампиры не против полакомиться жителями деревни. Это увлекает и забавляет, а также в этот момент вы строите в голове сотни комбинаций с другими картами, которые вы можете применить в своем забеге.
Но комбинаций не очень много, и вы быстро их запомните, а также (по моему мнению) не хватает счётчика ландшафтных карт.
[b]9/10[/b]

[h3]Графика[/h3]
Я люблю пиксель-арты, и здесь всё идеально. Нет ярких цветов, что подобает мрачному сюжету. Очень понравились арты снаряжения и, особенно, боссов, что делает их незабываемыми врагами и примером отличного и продуманного врага. За всю игру мы увидим 2 кат-сцены и они шедевральны. Я даже поделился ими с друзьями, настолько мне они понравились, настолько в них влили душу.
[b]10/10[/b]

[h3]Саундтрек[/h3]
Очень понравился саундтрек в лагере, в первой кат-сцене и в титрах [spoiler]и в босс-файте с Омегой[/spoiler]. Когда его слушаешь, в голове так и возникают образы смерти и неизбежного конца, что очень сильно погружает в атмосферу и без того мрачного сюжета. blinch (автор сего аудио-творения) постарался на славу.
В остальных случаях — музыка просто подходит под стиль игры: не особо затянута, без сильных битов, не запоминается, и ощущается заЦИКЛенной (ba-dum-tss).
[b]9/10[/b]

[h3]Итог[/h3]
Мне очень понравился данный рогалик. После The Binding of Isaac и Enter the Gungeon почувствовал что-то новое и необычное. Советую поиграть в данный шедевр тем, кто либо знаком с рогаликами и ищет точку интереса, либо тем, кто обожает пиксели и читать.
У меня всё. Благодарю Four Quarters за данный инди-шедевр, а вас за прочтение данного обзора.
[h2]10/10[/h2] | 玩的差不多了后觉得这游戏挺可惜的，创意确实很亮眼，当年还被TGA提名过，但是呢制作组并没有深耕的打算导致游戏就像个半成品一样。
1：作为主打肉鸽的游戏可重复游玩性却不如人意，到后期基本上就是无聊的刷，这一点可以说是致命的
2：游戏的自由度太高，而在前期惩罚也太高导致初上手的挫败感很强，新手引导特别不过关
3：到后期输了没感觉，赢了也没感觉，唯一感受到的就是时间流逝
总结的说，制作组愿意深耕的话以上问题都有解决的办法，凭借这个创意说不定可以做出一款里程碑式的作品，可惜他们并不在意，不过话说回来打折后的价格性价比没得说，值得喜欢独立游戏的各位买一个体验一下
 | La verdad es que este juego lo llevo jugando desde que salio, sin embargo lo jugaba pirateado en vieja pc, en cuanto mejore con respecto a pc lo primero que compre fue este juego y no eh parado de jugarlo. | I'd give it a 7/10

I had a lot of fun playing this game on my steamdeck while traveling but I will 100% say this game feels kind of unfinished and poorly balanced. A lot of my enjoyment was derived from trying to figure out how to win on the harder difficulties with each character in spite of the poor balancing. 

It's definitely a neat concept that I havent seen done before and I enjoyed discovering neat combinations of tiles on the map like Village + Vampire Manor = Vampire Town. But I wish there was more of that. There should be dozens and dozens of combinations and interactions, but there's really not. It feels like there's content waiting to be implemented but it just never came. 

It's got some soft "gambling" elements in that you can end runs early to cash in your treasure or you can always go for another loop or attempt a boss in an all-or-nothing kind of way. It's fun but frustrating in a not so great way. | Fantastic game and gorgeous visuals, normally not a fan of grindy games, but this feels like you make genuine progress every time you play

Tho one thing linux users should know, make sure compatibility layer uses the latest version of proton!

Genres: Casual, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Early Access
Reviews:
Most Early Access Games I'm pretty chill about, I play what's there and then forget about it for months. I think this is the first game in a LONG time that I am sitting here screaming, crying, throwing up that it is not fully out yet.
That is to say: I think I'm genuinely quite bad at several of the vital components of this game and I'm STILL having a fantastic time. Everything comes together in a really fascinating way I don't think I've seen in many games before. Friendship is VITAL to story progression and battling capabilities, farming is closely tied to your ability to upgrade your blob's health and stamina, several items can ONLY be found in blob worlds... It's genuinely engaging to be forced to interact with every aspect of the game so naturally! Even the battle level-up system is unique! I'm not just spamming my strongest attack every battle, because if I do so, my blobs will actually get WEAKER since I'm only leveling one of three attributes. It's an incredible experience and I look forward to vibrating with intensity while patiently waiting for more updates to come :) | I would recommend Ova Magica to anyone who enjoys the farming/life sim style games. Claudia the dev has done a phenomenal job of listening to feedback both from steam and discord.

Pros 
- Combat is both easy to learn and intricate enough to be enjoyable
- Farming is worth it, as you need many of the crops to upgrade Blobs
- The NPCs all have unique personalities, and they are carefully created
- The blob worlds are procedural generated, so each visit yields different rewards

Cons
- The leveling system of the blobs' stats took me a while to catch on (this seems to have been addressed in v0.8 with the blob training

The game is still in early access, so the game is still improving. Each update has given hours of new gameplay so I am excited to see what 2025 brings for the game! | This is such a cute game! I can't wait for it to fully release. It reminds me of Pokemon and Harvest moon. |  It's a mix of all the best parts of farm and creature collection games. It's very incomplete at the moment but I'm already falling in love with it's potential. | This game has it all tons of fun and I love the new content they are adding even though the game is still in early access there is so much fun to be had. Highly recommend this game it has blobs you can catch, fishing,farming and crafting.

Damn I can't believe I finally finished this. Officially my 2nd most played game on Steam o.o

Going into this I knew it was a mobile port, so I wasn't expecting *much*, maybe the other reviewers didn't know that, but either way I think "mostly negative" is a tad bit harsh.

Yeah the game is very very basic, it lacks pretty much all the basic things you'd expect from a nonogram:

- Doesn't cross off completed numbers/hints. You don't even get the option to do it yourself.
- No accessibility settings at all, even basic stuff like background colour change/font size etc.
- Like stated above, the font size is TINY on bigger nonograms, for basically no reason as there is 100% space for them to be larger. I often confused 8 with 6 as well as 3 and 5 ALL the time and it of course isn't a good thing to get the numbers wrong. 
- In my opinion the "what line you have hovered over" indicator needs to be waaay darker. I struggled to see which line I was on often.
- Puzzle sizes are random (apart from maybe the first few), so sometimes you get thrown a bunch of easy, and then a lot of hards, no matter where you are in progress. If that's your thing then cool, but sometimes you just wanna do one or the other. You can't skip ahead on levels so you can't just go pick another level either.
- It's very easy to mess up and click a square by accident, so you either clear it or turn it into an x/filled. Literally every other nonogram game I've played stops you being able to paint over X's.
- A lot of wording is clearly from the mobile game which they haven't bothered changing for the PC version, like "tap" instead of click.
- Lack of title/description for finished pictures. Sometimes I still had no idea what they were even when they were completed/coloured in. 

There's honestly probably a bunch more things I've forgotten. But all I'm really saying is the game is very very basic, but I clearly enjoyed it hence the 130 hours playtime, so rating badly would just be stupid of me. That doesn't mean I can't advise you against playing, because imo there are plenty of better nonogram games on Steam (I just happened to have already played most of them already). 

 | I'm still playing for some inexplicable reason, but there are much better picross/nonogram games out there.

If you're stuck on a puzzle, there is no way to progress other than to just keep trying or pay more money. This model is common in mobile games but unexpected and frustrating in Steam games. | [u]Recommendation[/u]: Good value for a while, but eventually I stopped enjoying it when the puzzles could no longer be solved with logic alone.

[u]Review[/u]: You are exploring the world's desserts, sampling sweets all over the world as you travel across abstracted, goofy versions of several continents. Completing each puzzle reveals a picture of some dessert or dessert-related item: a bonbon, an ice cream cone, a gumball machine, and so forth. As with any freemium game, you can play the entire game for free from beginning to end, or you can buy coins (which are used to travel) or hints for real money. The puzzles quickly get difficult enough that using a hint will be really tempting, but you can use the coins that accumulate for free over time as well. I tried to complete one puzzle a day, and at that rate I never had to pay money, and my ability to use logic to determine which spaces have to be part of the picture and which spaces cannot be part of the picture - the whole point of nonogram puzzles - was sufficient to complete every puzzle...up until a point.

Unfortunately for me, I am simultaneously working my way through two other nonogram puzzle games, and I have played several others in the past. This game suffers in the comparison. There are a bunch of little things done in other nonogram games that in this Picross Bonbon game are either inferior or flat-out missing. Together these little things eventually added up to my realization that I was continuing to play not because I was enjoying the game but because I was reluctant to give up on something I'd started. That coincided with a big step up in difficulty of the puzzles the game was presenting.

But I *did* enjoy this game to begin with; the puzzles on the first continent represent a nice progression in difficulty, without being so complex that the UI issues and missing features scream in your face. I think it's pretty good value at first, and then that diminishes the further you get in the game. 

[u]Critique[/u]: First of all, I should point out that this game has a user interface seemingly modeled after mobile games. I don't know if it is a port of a mobile game or a game that was simultaneously released across different platforms, but there's a bunch of mobile game features present here. This isn't a huge issue for me, but I know it is a sticking point for some. For example, there's the three-star rating system for each puzzle: complete a puzzle and you are awarded one, two, or three stars. There's also a goofy menu system of nested screens, so if you want to quit the game, you have to bring up the menu, select the map icon, return to the map, then click the "return/go back" arrow, return to the title screen, then click the "X" icon to quit the game...rather than the usual game convention of bringing up the ESC menu and selecting "Quit." Like I said, it's a lot of little things like this that ultimately make the game irritating to play.

But I could overlook those if the gameplay interface was better. For better or worse (I say worse), the puzzle gameplay in Picross Bonbon is the closest to what I imagine playing a nonogram in a book or newspaper would be like: the interface doesn't tell you whether you've put the marks in the correct place, nor does it tell you whether you've completed a row or column correctly. It will tell you that the conditions of the row or column have been met: you have put in 8 - 2 - 5 - 1 in that column...but you could have put them in randomly, and they could be completely incorrect.

However, the biggest, most egregious foul in the nonogram gameplay to my mind is that you will eventually reach puzzles where you have to GUESS (or use a hint). One should absolutely never, EVER have to guess when solving a logic puzzle. When you work on solving a logic puzzle, you need to KNOW that if you are guessing in that logic puzzle, you're missing something. But in this game, you WILL get to the point where you have to make a blind choice between two or three possible locations for a mark, and then you have to play through a bunch more of the puzzle before you discover whether you guessed correctly. Of course, you can consider that your guess might be a bit more "educated" if you consider the picture that is being formed and choose something that fits better with the image. Your mileage may vary, but this is just terrible to me.

I suspect that the game designers want to present you with situations where you can't know what the right choice is, or reason out the correct choice, so that you will spend currency on hints that will reveal the truth to you without ever showing you WHY you mark one space and not another. That idea - that you would make a logic puzzle that cannot be solved by logic - is so filthy to me I had a hard time getting my fingers to type it through my disgust.

I couldn't believe it at first, but then the situation where I had to guess started recurring more and more often. It's not a fluke. It's a very broken feature of the game. I hate giving up on a game without finishing it, but here I could not finish it without guessing or using "hints" to solve it for me. So I'm going to have to give up on this one. | 画面很可爱，地图上Q弹的果冻超萌，作为数图类游戏算比较复杂的，错误时没有提示。
不知为何，明明已经获取了其它所有成就，最后一个“获取全部奖杯”的成就无论如何都点不亮，可能是个BUG，成就控慎入…… | This is why one should always read the reviews before buying. I saw that this was a picross/nonogram game and I purchased it immediately without reading the reviews. Big Mistake. Turns out, this is the worst nonogram game I've ever played on steam, and I have many of them in my collection.

In this game, you can't mark a specific number as done, hence making you count each square again if you're playing the bigger puzzles. 

You have to be soooo careful while filling the squares because you can easily unmark them or mark another square. 

Dragging a line with lift click or right click will immediately replace a square with different input that you've already filled earlier, like for example, you can't just drag your mouse to mark the rest of the row as X because it will overwrite the squares on the column on its path that you've already marked before! This to me is the deal-breaker as its the most stupid UX design for a nonogram game.

The learning curve is also crazy, you start off with medium and hard puzzles immediately, lolz. I'm ok with that as I'm a seasoned nonogram player but beginners will find this difficult.

Conclusion: I never knew it was possible to rage quit a nonogram game until I played this one.

Not a bad game per session, and I was actually having a lot of fun. Until I went to multiplayer.

The movement there is just broken to the point of being unplayable.
Everyone makes the orders on their turn, then the movement and attacks happen in a seemingly random order.
This means that if you're the last in turn order you can get your big unit move blocked by a scout. 
You'll get shot first before getting to do anything. 
You'll get flanked because you've not moved yet, so the enemy has perfect knowledge.
You'll have your disembarks move blocked - the charge card you paid for? Wasted. Pick a different cell next turn? Then can just move to it.

It's not just bad, it's infuriatingly unfair if you're not player 1. | Unlike some other games, you do not need to spend a whole days working at a map; sometimes a half hour is enough, leaving you time to play another round or just to avoid the necessity of trying to cram two hours of sleep before the morning alarm clock. There are many modes to try; I particularly like the Hegemony battles - not because I always win but because I sometimes don't although I wish there were a forum for each of the various civilisations (factions) so that I could see if there are other players that consistently favour one or some civs over others rather than just wondering if folks are merely jumping onto the bandwagon of the one leading faction.. The developers are good at staying on top of the little issues. | Very nice game, but unfortunately very badly balanced... to bad!

Will give it a thumps up anyways, because besides the balance its pretty neat. | Low online in MP but otherwise a great game. I just wish it got updated more often | the more I play it, the more I like it. gives a pretty great 4x experience in a reasonable time session.
